reasoning: The critique targets a central inferential step: translating “no de dicto optimization” into “little optimization pressure toward high value,” hence low frequency of mostly-great futures. If de re/endogenous selection reliably builds moral/institutional guardrails, that would undercut a substantial portion of the paper’s empirical/probabilistic conclusion about rarity among survival-conditioned futures (though not all of the paper’s moral-theoretic case that many views are fussy). Strength is moderate-low because it mostly asserts a plausible countervailing mechanism (institutional/selection dynamics) without showing it robustly handles the specific failure modes the paper highlights (population ethics, digital minds, cosmic resource allocation, fat-tailed value efficiency, etc.), many of which could persist or worsen under competition; it calls for a model rather than providing one. Correctness is fairly high: it’s true that optimization can be de re, endogenous, and can create convergent constraints, and it’s fair to say the paper would need to argue these dynamics fail if it relies on their absence. Clarity is good and focused, with little dead weight, and it is largely a single-issue “equilibrium/selection dynamics” objection. Overall, it’s a reasonable challenge but not yet a decisive problem for the position.
title: De re selection pressures may create convergent moral guardrails without de dicto optimization
